## Overview

Diabetes, Cardiovascular Disease and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease are all diseases that greatly affect mortality rates in the United States annually. This resource shows how these diseases vary in different states as well as specific groups of people such as males, females and people of different race and ethnicities. It shows how the numbers have changed over time from 2010 to 2014. The graphic above shows the combined mortality count for all three diseases for different time periods. Data specific to each disease can be seen under the "Graphics" tab. Information pertaining to the purpose of our research and the source of our data can be found under the "Documentation" tab.

It is seen that California, Texas, New York and Florida are the Top 4 states with the highest total mortality rate. This is unsuprising as the the following states have the highest population in the country. Of the three diseases, it is evident that Cardiovascular Disease results in the highest mortalities as heart disease is the leading cause of death in the United States. It is also one of the most costly disease when health care spending and lost productivity is taken into account.
